export const articlesData = [
  {
    id: 1,
    title: "How Human Resources Drives Waste Management Improvement",
    date: "October 10, 2025",
    image: "https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1532996122724-e3c354a0b15b?q=80&w=2070&auto=format&fit=crop",
    excerpt: "Human Resources (HR) is one of the most vital, yet often overlooked, drivers of effective waste management in any organization. Waste reduction and proper disposal are fundamentally behavioral issues. By using its expertise in training, safety, and communication, HR transforms waste management from a simple operational requirement into a core part of the company culture.",
    content: [
      "By Training Staff in Segregation and Recycling Techniques",
      "HR develops and delivers mandatory training programs to all employees and new hires. This training focuses on the proper sorting of materials (paper, plastic, e-waste, organics) and minimizing contamination. By standardizing knowledge and using clear visual guides, HR ensures compliance and fosters a culture of proper waste segregation at the source, which is critical for successful recycling.",
      "By Implementing Safety Measures for Waste Handlers",
      "HR works with Health & Safety to protect employees involved in waste collection and disposal. This includes conducting risk assessments for all waste streams (especially hazardous materials like batteries and chemicals), ensuring staff are equipped with the correct Personal Protective Equipment (PPE), and providing specialized training on safe handling protocols to prevent injury.",
      "By Raising Public Awareness Campaigns",
      "HR utilizes internal and external communication channels to promote the company's commitment to waste reduction. Internally, campaigns boost employee engagement and recognize 'Green Champions.' Externally, highlighting sustainability achievements enhances the employer brand, attracts eco-conscious talent, and demonstrates the organization's corporate social responsibility to the public and stakeholders."
    ]
  },
  {
    id: 2,
    title: "The Waste Hierarchy: Recycling is Your Last Resort, Not the First",
    date: "October 8, 2025",
    image: "https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1532996122724-e3c354a0b15b?q=80&w=2070&auto=format&fit=crop",
    excerpt: "The most powerful thing you can do for the planet is prevent waste from being created in the first place. Think of the 5 R's as a checklist where the top items are the most important.",
    content: [
      "ðŸ¥‡ Rank 1: Refuse & Reduce",
      "Say 'No' to single-use plastics and packaging. Buy less stuff overall. This saves the most energy, water, and raw materials because you avoid manufacturing entirely.",
      "Why It Matters: This is the most impactful action you can take. When you refuse unnecessary items and reduce your consumption, you prevent waste at its source. No manufacturing means no energy consumption, no water usage, no raw material extraction, and no transportation emissions.",
      "ðŸ¥ˆ Rank 2: Reuse & Repurpose",
      "Fix, donate, or find a new creative use for an item before you toss it. This extends the product's life and delays its trip to the landfill or recycling plant.",
      "Why It Matters: Every time you reuse an item, you're getting more value from the resources that went into making it. Repairing instead of replacing, donating instead of discarding, and repurposing items creatively keeps materials in use longer and reduces demand for new products.",
      "ðŸ¥‰ Rank 3: Recycle",
      "Only after all other options have failed, place items (clean and sorted!) into the correct bin. Recycling still requires significant energy. It's the best end-of-life option, but not the best first choice.",
      "Why It Matters: While recycling is better than landfilling, it still consumes energy and resources to collect, sort, clean, and reprocess materials. Contaminated recyclables can ruin entire batches. Recycling should be your last resort after you've exhausted all options to refuse, reduce, and reuse."
    ]
  },
  {
    id: 3,
    title: "Food Waste: A Methane Monster in the Landfill",
    date: "October 6, 2025",
    image: "https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1542601906990-b4d3fb778b09?q=80&w=2013&auto=format&fit=crop",
    excerpt: "When you throw away food, you're not just wasting money; you're fueling climate change.",
    content: [
      "Methane is the Problem",
      "When food rots in a landfill (without oxygen), it releases methane (CHâ‚„). Methane is a greenhouse gas 80 times more potent than carbon dioxide in the short term. This means that every piece of food waste in a landfill is actively contributing to global warming at an accelerated rate.",
      "The anaerobic decomposition process in landfills creates the perfect environment for methane production. Without oxygen, organic matter breaks down differently than it would in nature, producing this powerful greenhouse gas that traps heat in our atmosphere much more effectively than COâ‚‚.",
      "Waste of Resources",
      "Wasted food means wasted land, wasted water, and wasted energy used to grow, transport, and cook it. Every apple thrown away represents gallons of water used for irrigation, acres of farmland, fuel for transportation, and energy for refrigeration and cooking.",
      "Consider the full lifecycle: farmers worked the land, used pesticides and fertilizers, harvested the crops, trucked them to distribution centers, stored them in refrigerated warehouses, delivered them to stores, and you brought them home. All of that effort and resource consumption is wasted when food ends up in the trash.",
      "The Simple Solution: Compost",
      "The best final destination for food scraps (peels, cores, coffee grounds) is composting. Composting uses oxygen, which converts the waste into beneficial soil nutrients instead of climate-warming methane.",
      "When you compost, you're completing nature's cycle. Organic matter breaks down aerobically (with oxygen) to create nutrient-rich soil amendment that helps plants grow, retains moisture, and sequesters carbon. This transforms a climate problem into a climate solution while reducing the need for chemical fertilizers."
    ]
  },
  {

    title: "The Circular Economy: Ending the Take-Make-Dispose Loop",
    date: "October 4, 2025",
    image: "https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1532996122724-e3c354a0b15b?q=80&w=2070&auto=format&fit=crop",
    excerpt: "We need to fundamentally change the Take (extract) â†’ Make (product) â†’ Dispose (waste) system. The Circular Economy is a revolutionary idea designed to solve the waste problem at its root.",
    content: [
      "Design Out Waste",
      "Companies make products that are guaranteed to last and can be completely disassembled and remade. This means products are designed from the beginning with their entire lifecycle in mindâ€”not just how they'll be used, but how they'll be repaired, upgraded, and eventually returned to the manufacturing cycle.",
      "Your Action - Demand Durability: Support brands that offer lifetime warranties or repair services. Vote with your wallet by choosing companies that prioritize longevity over planned obsolescence. Look for products with modular designs that can be easily repaired and upgraded.",
      "When you buy a product designed to last decades instead of years, you're supporting a fundamental shift in how things are made. Companies that offer repair programs, spare parts, and upgrade options are demonstrating their commitment to circularity.",
      "Circulate Value",
      "Products are repaired and reused constantly, keeping materials in the economy for as long as possible. Instead of extracting new raw materials, we maximize the use of existing materials by keeping them in circulation through repair, refurbishment, and remanufacturing.",
      "Your Action - Fix It: Don't replaceâ€”repair! Support local businesses that specialize in fixing things. Learn basic repair skills yourself through online tutorials and community repair workshops. Share your repair successes to inspire others.",
      "Every time you repair instead of replace, you're keeping valuable materials out of the waste stream and reducing demand for new production. The circular economy only works if we, as consumers, actively participate by choosing repair over disposal and supporting businesses that make repair possible and affordable."
    ]
  }
